prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ending free friend rides in my car?
My friend always hops rides everywhere in my car. I fill up the tank and pick him up at his house and drop him back off safely at home. This past weekend he put 10 in gas because I forgot my purse home and yesterday he asked me back for it. He has ridden in my car hundreds of times without putting gas. Am I an asshole for saying find your way around in the future?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for ending free rides for their friend. So, the situation is that the friend has been taking rides in the author's car many times without contributing to gas. This time, the author forgot their purse, so the friend put in $10 for gas, and then yesterday the author asked the friend back for that. The author is now telling the friend to find their way around instead.

First, I need to figure out the key points here. The friend has been getting free rides hundreds of times. The author is now ending it, and the friend put $10 once. The author is asking if they're an asshole for doing that. 

So, from the author's perspective, maybe they feel taken advantage of. They've been covering all the gas costs without any contribution from the friend. It's reasonable for someone to expect some contribution from a friend who uses their car frequently. But when the friend did contribute $10 once, the author asked them back for it. That seems a bit contradictory. If the author is now expecting the friend to cover gas costs, but then when the friend does contribute, the author is asking for that money back, maybe that's where the issue is. 

Wait, the friend put $10 because the author forgot their purse. That might have been a one-time thing. Then the author is saying to find their own way around in the future. The problem is, the friend has been using the car without contributing for hundreds of times. The author is now cutting off rides. 

But the author asked back the $10 the friend put in. That's confusing. If the author is now done with the rides, then maybe they shouldn't have taken the $10 back. Alternatively, the author might have realized that expecting the friend to pay for gas every time is too much, so they just want to end the arrangement. 

Is the author in the wrong? Well, the friend was using the author's car without contributing. So the author has the right to set boundaries. But taking back the $10 might be seen as unfair. If the friend offered money once, maybe the author should accept it instead of returning it. But maybe the author is saying that since they're ending the arrangement, they won't accept any more payments. 

The main question is whether the author is an asshole for ending the free rides. The friend was using the car a lot without contributing. It's reasonable for the author to want to stop this if they don't want to. So the answer might be B, the author is not in the wrong. However, the part about taking back the $10 might be a point. If the author is ending the rides, they shouldn't have asked for the money back. But maybe that's a separate issue. The main point is the author is ending the ride-sharing because they don't want to subsidize the friend's transportation. 

So overall, the author is within their rights to set boundaries. They can choose to stop providing rides if they feel it's becoming a burden. The friend's one-time contribution doesn't change the fact that they've been using the car without paying. Therefore, the author isn't in the wrong.
